titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Maurice Rea Davie Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by John Espy and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:38

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence of Maurice Rea Davie, primarily with Albert G. Keller, writings, subject files, and photographs.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Maurice Rea Davie Papers (MS 1359). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Albert J. Reiss, Jr., 1978; Douglas Davie, 1990; and transferred from YRG 37-V, 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These papers consist of correspondence and printed matter sent by the National Institute of Immigrant Welfare to Maurice R. Davie, a member of the Institute's Board of Directors. Most of the letters concern either requests for Davie to speak, or such routine business matters as committee meetings, dues, and financial problems. Professor Albert. J. Reiss, Jr., of the Yale Sociology Department, gave these papers to the Manuscripts and Archives Department in April 1978.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Maurice Rea Davie was born in Toronto, Canada, on January 22, 1893. He received his A.B. (1915), A.M. (1917), and Ph.D. (1918) from Yale University. Davie was a member of the sociology department at Yale from 1921 until his death in November 1964. Among his areas of speciality were child welfare, immigration, and William Graham Sumner.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.
